metadata.title: A Novel Framework of Cooperative Design: Bringing Active Fault Diagnosis Into Fault-Tolerant Control
metadata.abstract: Fault-tolerant control (FTC) may conceal fault symptoms, thereby increasing the difficulty of fault diagnosis (FD). In this article, a novel framework for the cooperative design of active FD and FTC is proposed to optimize FD performance while maintaining fault-tolerance performance. The proposed framework consists of four steps: 1) controller design; 2) residual generation; 3) performance evaluation; and 4) gain tuning. First, a controller with undetermined gains is constructed, and a fault detection observer is designed to generate residuals that can indicate the fault. Then, the performance of fault detection is evaluated. Finally, suboptimal controller gains are obtained by solving an optimization problem. Within the framework of the collaborative design, the occurring faults can be detected faster and more accurately, and the performance of FTC can be guaranteed at the same time. A simulation study is provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the developed framework.

grobid.contents:
A Novel Framework of Cooperative Design: Bringing Active Fault Diagnosis Into Fault-Tolerant Control
MAY 2023

Fanlin Jia 
Fangfei Cao 
Guangran Lyu 
Senior Member, IEEEXiao He 
A Novel Framework of Cooperative Design: Bringing Active Fault Diagnosis Into Fault-Tolerant Control

IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON CYBERNETICS
5353301MAY 202310.1109/TCYB.2022.3176538
Fault-tolerant control (FTC) may conceal fault symptoms, thereby increasing the difficulty of fault diagnosis (FD). In this article, a novel framework for the cooperative design of active FD and FTC is proposed to optimize FD performance while maintaining fault-tolerance performance. The proposed framework consists of four steps: 1) controller design; 2) residual generation; 3) performance evaluation; and 4) gain tuning. First, a controller with undetermined gains is constructed, and a fault detection observer is designed to generate residuals that can indicate the fault. Then, the performance of fault detection is evaluated. Finally, suboptimal controller gains are obtained by solving an optimization problem. Within the framework of the collaborative design, the occurring faults can be detected faster and more accurately, and the performance of FTC can be guaranteed at the same time. A simulation study is provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the developed framework.Index Terms-Active fault diagnosis (AFD), cooperative design, fault-tolerant control (FTC), gain tuning, input design.

I. INTRODUCTION

W ITH the rapid development of advanced technology, modern engineering systems, such as flight control systems and underwater vehicle systems, are becoming increasingly complicated, with more and more powerful functions. However, the working environment of the modern system is not always ideal, and the systems are more inclined to suffer from faults [1]- [6]. Due to the increasing demands for system safety, reliability, and maintainability, fault diagnosis (FD) and fault-tolerant control (FTC) techniques have attracted a lot of attention, and rich results have been reported [7]- [12].

In the research field of FD, diagnostic systems were often designed separately from the controller [13]. It is worth noting that FD and FTC are coupled and interact with each other. The accuracy of FD directly affects the performance of FTC, and a delay of fault detection or isolation will lead to a significant degradation of system performance or even cause the instability of the entire system. On the other hand, FTC may mask the characteristics of the faults, which will decrease the accuracy of FD. In traditional passive FTC (PFTC), the fault is handled robustly without considering the FD process. The active FTC (AFTC) technique, combining the FD module and FTC protocol, allows the fault-tolerant controller to handle more complex faults [14]- [21]. However, an important feature of AFTC is that it relies heavily on the performance of FD. In general, the operating process of a modern system with fault occurrence can be divided into three stages: 1) fault-free stage (FFS); 2) transient stage (TS); and 3) fault-post stage (FPS), illustrated in Fig. 1. Here, t f stands for the time instant at which a fault occurs, and t d is the time instant at which a fault is detected [14]. It is worth noting that the system dynamics in the period from t f to t d are more complex and the system is prone to anomalies since no actions are undertaken to compensate for the faults [22]. In TS, the system is suffering from a fault, while the information provided by the FD unit still indicates that the system is fault free, so the system will maintain the terrible situation. Besides, the dynamic characteristics of a linear FTC system were analyzed in [23], and it was found that even a short delay in fault detection may seriously affect the system stability. On the one hand, for PFTC, it is difficult to realize FD on the premise of ensuring the faulttolerant performance since PFTC will cover fault symptoms. On the other hand, for AFTC, if the fault detection delay is too long, the system may lose its stability in TS before the fault is detected. Consequently, it is an urgent to design a collaborative design (CoD) algorithm of FD and FTC, which can not only guarantee the performance of the control system but also optimize the performance of FD.

Unlike the passive FD (PFD) framework that only uses system input and output data without any influence on the operation of the system, active FD (AFD) can increase the diagnostic capability for specific faults by injecting predesigned auxiliary signals into the systems [24]- [26]. Compared with PFD [27]- [32], the key of AFD is the design of auxiliary input signal. In general, the optimal input signal is designed to enhance the performance of FD by solving an optimal problem [26]. The idea of AFD provides a new inspiration for CoD. Thanks to the advantage that AFD can enhance the performance of FD, AFD may be adopted in CoD. However, the existing AFD methods are only devoted to considering the detection performance without considering the performance of FTC [33]- [37]. Besides, most AFD methods need to cut off the original control input of the system [24], and there is only the designed auxiliary input signal to be added into the system, which may be unrealistic in most practical systems. To the best of our knowledge, the cooperative design of AFD and FTC for optimizing FD performance and maintaining the performance of FTC is still an open problem, which constitutes the main focus of this article. The difficulty of the problem mainly lies in three aspects: 1) how to design a specific fault-tolerant controller, where different input signals can lead to different residuals of an AFD observer; 2) which form of the AFD observer can change the fault detection performance by changing the input; and 3) how to construct an optimization problem to obtain a suboptimal input signal of AFD.

In this article, a novel CoD framework of AFD and FTC is proposed. Fig. 2 shows the sketch of the proposed framework, including both the model-based techniques and the model-free (data-driven) methods. The novelty is that we introduce AFD into the design process of FTC. An adaptive fault-tolerant controller with undetermined gains is designed to ensure the system stability. Based on the performance evaluation of FD, a learning-based or intelligent algorithm is carried out to tune gains by using the state data of the system. In this way, CoD is realized by transforming the input optimization problem into the controller gains optimization problem. To summarize, the main contributions of this work can be stated as follows.

1) We have made one of the first attempts to propose a novel framework of the cooperative design of AFD and FTC, which can maintain the performance of asymptotic tracking and optimize the performance of FD at the same time. 2) Utilizing a specific fault detection observer, the suboptimal input design problem is transformed into an optimization problem for solving controller gains.

3) The proposed algorithm has the advantages of both the model-based and model-free methods, which can not only ensure the stability of the system but also have the flexibility of model-free learning algorithms. The remainder of this article is organized as follows. In Section II, problem statement and preliminary are given. The CoD algorithm is presented in Section III. Section IV gives the main results of the proposed algorithm. A simulation example is provided in Section V. Some concluding remarks are represented in Section VI.


II. PROBLEM STATEMENT AND PRELIMINARY

Consider a second-order single-input-single-output (SISO) nonlinear system with actuator faults and disturbances as follows:ẋ
1 (t) = x 2 (t) x 2 (t) = f (x(t)) + bu(t) + d(t) y(t) = x 1 (t)(1)
where x 1 and x 2 are state variables,
x(t) = [x 1 (t), x 2 (t)] T , y(t)
represents the output, u(t) is the input of the system whose component may have multiplicative faults during operation, b is a known positive constant, and d(t) denotes the unknown bounded time-varying disturbance. For simplicity, the argument (t) will be omitted in the following contents in the case of no confusion. For example, let x i and y represent x i (t) and y(t) respectively. The actuator fault considered here is modelled as follows:
u = σ u 0(2)
where σ ∈ (0, 1) describes the partial loss of the effectiveness coefficient, and u 0 is the control input signal to be designed. Before representing the problem formulation, we give the definition of CoD of AFD and FTC.

Definition 1 (CoD of AFD and FTC): AFD and FTC are realized at the same time under a unified design framework. With the occurrence of faults, a controller, which can not only ensure the performance of FTC but also detect the fault in the shortest time, is constructed to generate suboptimal control input signal.

Problem: This article aims to realize the CoD of AFD and FTC for a class of systems with actuator faults and unknown disturbance such that: 1) the output signal y can track the reference signal y d , and the tracking error asymptotically converges to 0; 2) under a specific fault detection observer, the fault can be detected as quickly as possible; and 3) all states contained in the systems are uniformly bounded.

The goal of fault detection in this article is to find out a suboptimal controller gain that can reflect the fault maximally. Meanwhile, the objective of FTC is to make the tracking error converge to 0.

Remark 1: For some practical systems, such as manipulators, spacecrafts, and submersibles, due to the complexity of the environment, actuators are susceptible to faults during operation, which may result in unsatisfactory performance or instability. The proposed cooperative design algorithm can provide certain fault-tolerance performance and enhance the safety of the systems. Furthermore, the earlier the fault is detected, the sooner certain measures can be taken to prevent severe consequences.

Assumption 1: The desired reference signal y d and its timederivativesẏ d andÿ are supposed to be known, that is,
|y d | ≤ Y 0 , |ẏ d | ≤ Y 1 , and |ÿ d | ≤ Y 2 , smooth and bounded. Assumption 2: The external disturbance d(t) satisfies |d(t)| ≤ D, where D is a known positive constant. Lemma 1 (Barbalat's Lemma [38]): If ς(t) is a uni- formly continuous function on [0, ∞) and there exists a term ∞ 0 ς(τ )dτ which is finite, it will have lim t→∞ ς(t) = 0.

III. COD ALGORITHM DESIGN

In this section, a framework of cooperative design of AFD and FTC is proposed, shown in Fig. 3.

Step 1 (Controller Design): According to the system model, a controller is designed with undetermined gains, that is, u = H(K, x, y d ), where H(·) denotes the controller model, and K represents the control gain vector to be determined.

Step 2 (Fault Detection Observer Design): A fault detection observer is designed with proper parameters, that is, r = O(L, x, u, y d ), where r represents the residual which is used to indicate the fault, and L is a selected parameter of observer.

Step 3 (Evaluation of FD): A function is constructed to evaluate the performance of fault detection, that is, J(r), where r denotes the residual generated by the fault detection observer.

Step 4 (Gain Tuning): The input design is transformed into an optimization problem to solve suboptimal controller gains, that is, K = arg min φ(J(r)), where φ(·) represents a function of J(r).


A. Controller Design

Denote tracking error by e = y − y d , and taking timederivative of e yields thaṫ
e =ẋ 1 −ẏ d = x 2 −ẏ d .(3)
The sliding-mode function is designed as follows:
s = ce +ė (4)
where c is a positive constant.

Letting p = 1/(bσ ), then the actual control law is designed as
u 0 = −pα (5) with α = ks + cė + f (x) −ÿ d + D sgn(s)(6)
where k > 0 is one of the controller gains to be determined, D ≥ D, sgn(·) is signum function, andp is the estimate of p with the following adaptive updating law:
p = γ sα(7)
where γ > 0 is another gain to be determined.


B. Fault Detection Observer Design

In this part, an observer is designed to obtain the residual r = [r 1 , r 2 ] T . The dynamics of the observer is constructed as follows:λ
1 = λ 2 + l 1 (y − λ 1 ) + D 1 (y − λ 1 ) λ 2 = f (x) + bu 0 + D 2 (y − λ 1 )(8)
where l 1 , D 1 , and D 2 are pending positive constants satisfying
D 2 = 1 + l 1 D 1 .
The output of the observer is
r 1 = x 1 − λ 1 r 2 = x 2 − λ 2 − l 1 (y − λ 1 )(9)
where r 1 and r 2 represent the residuals which denote the feature of fault. Lemma 2: The designed observer (8) and (9) is exponentially stable in the absence of the external disturbances and faults.

Proof: First, consider the following Lyapunov function:
V r = 1 2 r 2 1 + 1 2 r 2 2 .(10)
Taking the time derivative of V r , then we havė
V r = r 1ṙ1 + r 2ṙ2 .(11)
From (1), (8), and (9),ṙ 1 andṙ 2 can be derived aṡ
r 1 =ẋ 1 −λ 1 = x 2 − λ 2 − (l 1 + D 1 )r 1 = r 2 − D 1 r 1(12)
anḋ
r 2 =ẋ 2 −λ 2 − l 1 ẋ 1 −λ 1 = bσ u 0 + d − bu 0 − D 2 r 1 − l 1 (x 2 − λ 2 − (l 1 + D 1 )r 1 ) = (bσ − b)u 0 + d − D 2 r 1 − l 1 r 2 + l 1 D 1 r 1 .(13)
Noting that D 2 = 1 + l 1 D 1 , substituting (12) and (13) into (11) leads tȯ
V r = r 1 r 2 − D 1 r 2 1 − D 2 r 1 r 2 + l 1 D 1 r 1 r 2 − l 1 r 2 2 + ((bσ − b)u 0 + d)r 2 = −D 1 r 2 1 − l 1 r 2 2 + ((bσ − b)u 0 + d)r 2 .(14)
In the absence of external disturbances and faults, that is, σ = 1 and d = 0, we havė
V r = −D 1 r 2 1 − l 1 r 2 2 ≤ 0.(15)
Due to V r ≥ 0 andV r ≤ 0, V r is bounded. Then, we can obtain that r 1 and r 2 are bounded.

From (15), the following inequality holds:
t 0V r dt ≤ − 1 t 0 |r| 2 dt(16)where 1 = min{l 1 , D 1 }. Then, we have V r (∞) − V r (0) ≤ − 1 ∞ 0 |r| 2 dt.(17)
Because of the boundness of V r (∞), the term ∞ 0 |r| 2 dt is bounded. According to Lemma 1, lim t→∞ |r| = 0, then r 1 → 0 and r 2 → 0. The proof is completed.

Lemma 3: For system (1) with external disturbances, the residual r exponentially converges to an invariant set containing the origin in the absence of the faults.

Proof: In the case of σ = 1 and d = 0, (14) is rewritten aṡ
V r = −D 1 r 2 1 − l 1 r 2 2 + r 2 d.(18)
According to Young's inequality and Assumption 2, we have that
r 2 d ≤ 1 2ε D 2 + ε 2 r 2 2(19)
where ε is a positive constant. Substituting (19) into (18) yieldṡ
V r ≤ −D 1 r 2 1 − l 1 − ε 2 r 2 2 + 1 2ε D 2 ≤ − 2 V r + 2(20)where 2 = min{2D 1 , 2l 1 − ε}, 2 = 1 2ε D 2 .
Multiplying both sides by e 2 t , (20) can be rewritten as
d V r (t)e 2 t dt ≤ 2 e 2 t .(21)
Furthermore, the following inequality can be obtained by integrating (21) over [0, t]:
V r ≤ V r (0)e − 2 t + 2 2 1 − e − 2 t(22)
which means that lim t→∞ 1 2
r 2 1 + 1 2 r 2 2 ≤ 2 2 .
Therefore, it is clear that the residual r converges to the invariant set S r 1 ,r 2 = {(r 1 , r 2 )|(1/2)r 2 1 + (1/2)r 2 2 ≤ ( 2 / 2 )} exponentially at a rate greater than e − 2 t . The proof is completed.

Remark 2:

The assumption that D is known is not a necessary condition for the CoD algorithm. In the controller design, D ≥ D is used to compensate for the effect of the disturbance, so the exact upper bound of d(t) is not required. In the fault detection observer design, D is used for performance analysis rather than the design process. Therefore, in the cooperative design, it is unnecessary to know the exact value of D. In practical application, D may be calculated or estimated in advance according to environmental conditions.


C. Evaluation Function

The residual evaluation function is defined by
J r (T) = T 0 r 2 1 + r 2 2 dt(23)
where T is the running time of the system. Based on the residual signal r, we propose the following evaluation strategy of fault detection:
J r > J th ⇒ fault detected J r ≤ J th ⇒ no fault
where J th represents a threshold that should be selected properly.

Remark 3: Define T * as the total time of system operation. In theory, the threshold can be selected as J th = (2 2 / 2 )T * . If J r (t 1 ) > (2 2 / 2 )T * , the fault will be detected at t 1 . However, the threshold for fault detection should be determined by repeated experiments or the experiences of experts in practice. This is due to the fact that when considering extreme situations, the threshold calculated by a theoretical criterion is prone to be conservative, which is, apparently, not suitable for practical engineering.

Remark 4: Note that the residual evaluation (23) increases over time and the existence of faults will accelerate the rise of this function. When there is no fault, the value of J r is very small. As long as an appropriate threshold J th is chosen, when there is no fault, the false alarm will not occur during the system operation time.


D. Gain Tuning

In the following content, the input design problem is transformed into an optimization problem to solve the suboptimal gains of the controller in order to detect the faults more rapidly.

Let t d be the detection time, that is, J r (t d ) > J th and
J r (t − d ) ≤ J th , where t − d represents the left moment of t d .
Notice that k and γ are the controller parameters to be adjusted, so the problem of gain-tuning can be transformed into the following optimization problem:
[k, γ ] = arg min [k,γ ]∈ t d(24)
where represents a set of optional parameters. Problem (24) can be solved by intelligent optimization methods, such as the differential evolution (DE) algorithm, genetic algorithm (GA), etc. In this article, we use DE for tackling the optimization problem (24). The DE algorithm is an optimization algorithm based on the theory of swarm intelligence, which guides optimized search through group intelligence generated by the cooperation and competition between individuals in the group. The main advantages of DE are: few parameters to be determined, not easy to fall into local optimum, and fast convergence [39]- [41].


IV. MAIN RESULTS

In this section, the effectiveness of the CoD algorithm of AFD and FTC will be discussed in depth.


A. Stability Analysis of FTC

A prerequisite for successful CoD of AFD and FTC is that the designed FTC algorithm is effective.

The results of convergence analysis can be concluded in the following theorem.

Theorem 1: Consider system (1) with unknown external disturbance d and the actuator multiplicative fault (2), the control law (5), and the adaptive updating law (7). There exist proper controller gains k and γ such that: 1) the output signal can track the desired reference signal y d , and the tracking error asymptotically converges to 0; 2) all states contained in the systems are uniformly bounded. Proof: Taking the time derivative of sliding-mode function s yields thatṡ
= cė +ë = cė +ẋ 2 −ÿ d = cė + f (x) + bσ u 0 + d −ÿ d .(25)
Consider the Lyapunov function candidate as
V = 1 2 s 2 + bσ 2γp 2(26)
wherep =p − p. Then, we can obtain thaṫ
V = sṡ + bσ γpṗ(27)

Substituting (5), (7), and (25) into (27) leads tȯ
V = s(cė + f (x) + bσ u 0 + d −ÿ d ) + bσ γp γ sα = s(cė + f (x) + d −ÿ d ) − bσpsα + bσpsα = s(cė + f (x) + d −ÿ d ) − sα.(28)
From (6), we can obtaiṅ
V = −ks 2 + sd − sD sgn(s) ≤ −ks 2 ≤ 0.(29)
Because V ≥ 0 andV ≤ 0, V is bounded, we can obtain that s andp are bounded.

From (29), we know that
t 0V dt ≤ −k t 0 s 2 dt.(30)
Then, it holds that
V(∞) − V(0) ≤ −k ∞ 0 s 2 dt.(31)
Because of the boundness of V(∞), the term ∞ 0 s 2 dt is bounded. According to Lemma 1, lim t→∞ s = 0, then e → 0 andė → 0. It is concluded that the tracking error e asymptotically converges to 0. From Assumption 1, we know y d andẏ d are bounded. One can obtain x 1 = e + y d is bounded. Noticing thatė = x 2 −ẏ d , we can conclude that x 2 is bounded. The proof is completed.

Remark 5: From the expression of control law (5), when there is a large disturbance d, a sufficiently large upper bound of D needs to be guaranteed, which, however, may lead to a chattering phenomenon. In practical application, in order to prevent chattering, a saturation function sat(s) can be used instead of the signum function sgn(s), that is
sat(s) = ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ 1, s > ζ 1 ζ s, |s| ≤ ζ −1, s < −ζ
where ζ > 0 is a function of time t representing a boundary layer in sliding control, ζ satisfies t 0 ζ(τ )dτ ≤ζ < ∞ ∀t ≥ 0, andζ is a positive constant. For example, ζ(t) = 2e −0.05t . Then, the control law is designed as
u 0 = −p ks + cė + f (x) −ÿ d + D sat(s) .(32)
Using the improved control law (32), the conclusions in Theorem 1 still hold. See the Appendix for the proof.


B. Effectiveness of Fault Detection Observer

In this section, we will prove that the fault detection observer (8) can be used to detect a fault.

Theorem 2: Consider the nonlinear system (1) subject to the unknown external disturbance d and the actuator fault, and let l 1 , D 1 , and ε be predescribed positive constants. There exists an observer of the form (8) to generate the residual r which can be utilized for fault detection.

Proof: From the proof of Theorem 1, we have known that all states, s = ce +ė andp =p − p are bounded. According to the definition of u 0 (5) and Assumption 1, the boundedness of u 0 can be deduced.

Denote F(t) = (bσ − b)u 0 (t) as the fault effect, where |F(t)| ≤F, andF is a positive constant. Equation (14) can be written asV
r = −D 1 r 2 1 − l 1 r 2 2 + r 2 d + r 2 F.(33)
According to Young's inequality, one has that
r 2 F ≤ 1 2εF 2 + ε 2 r 2 2 .(34)
Substitute (19) and (34) into (33), then we havė
V r ≤ −D 1 r 2 1 − (l 1 − ε)r 2 2 + 1 2ε D 2 +F 2 ≤ − 3 V r + 3 (35) where 3 = min{2D 1 , 2(l 1 − ε)}, 3 = 1 2ε D 2 +F 2 . (36)
Similar to (21), we can obtain lim t→∞ 1 2
r 2 1 + 1 2 r 2 2 ≤ 3 3 .(37)
From Lemmas 2 and 3, it is convenient to obtain 0 < ( 2 / 2 ) < ( 3 / 3 ), so we can use residual r to indicate whether the actuator fault occurs or not. The proof is completed. Calculate u 0 according to the sub-optimal gains k and γ .


Algorithm 1 CoD of AFD and FTC

Remark 6: From (37), we can know that the set to which the residual converges in the absence of fault is not the same as that in the presence of fault. If (1/2)r 2 1 +(1/2)r 2 2 > ( 2 / 2 ) at a time t, the system must have a fault. Once a fault occurs during the system operation, the evaluation function will increase rapidly and soon exceed the selected threshold J th .


C. Effectiveness of the CoD Algorithm

We summarize the specific steps of the proposed CoD algorithm as shown in Algorithm 1.

Theorem 3: In Algorithm 1, with the help of a fault detection observer (8), the CoD of AFD and FTC can be achieved, that is, it can not only ensure the performance of FTC but also detect the fault in the shortest time by tuning the controller gains. The following properties can be satisfied at the same time.

1) With the selected threshold J th , the fault can be detected in the shortest time.

2) The output signal can track the desired reference signal y d , and the tracking error asymptotically converges to 0. 3) All states contained in the systems are uniformly bounded. Proof: From Theorem 1, for ∀k > 0 and ∀γ > 0, the performance of FTC can be ensured in theory, which means that properties 2) and 3) can be guaranteed by the designed controller (5).

According to Lemma 3 and Theorem 2, we know that the set of residual r that converges when a fault occurs is different from the set of residual r that converges when no fault occurs, which are 2 / 2 and 3 / 3 , respectively. Note that 2 / 2 is independent of the input signal u 0 . Subsequently, we only need to prove that the residuals r 1 and r 2 in the case of faults can be affected by changing the controller gains k and γ . Thereby, the value of the residual evaluation function will change so that it can be reached at threshold J th as quickly as possible after the fault occurs.

Denote t > 0 as an arbitrarily small interval. From (5), we can obtain Dsgn(s(t))). (38) Substituting (7) into (38) yields Dsgn(s(t))). (39) Combining F = (bσ −b)u 0 , (36) and (39), it can be inferred that r 1 and r 2 are related to the parameters k and γ . Therefore, we can use intelligent optimization methods like DE to find the suboptimal gains such that the residual evaluation function J can reach at J th in the shortest time when a fault occurs. The proof is completed.
u 0 (t) = − p(t − t) +ṗ(t − t) t × (ks(t) + cė(t) + f (x(t)) −ÿ d (t) +u 0 (t) = − p(t − t) + γ s(t − t) t × (ks(t − t) + cė(t − t) + f (x(t − t)) −ÿ d (t − t) + Dsgn(s(t − t)))) × (ks(t) + cė(t) + f (x(t)) −ÿ d (t) +
Remark 7: If the gain b in the considered system (1) is unknown, the CoD algorithm will not be applicable because the residual generated by the fault detection observer cannot be used to indicate the occurrence of the fault. Therefore, an important condition for the application of the algorithm is a known input gain b.

Remark 8: The proposed CoD framework is also applicable to the case of additive faults. If an additive fault is considered, the input u can be modelled as u 0 = σ u 0 + u a , where u a denotes the additive fault, |u a | ≤ū a andū a > 0 is a constant. Then, the actual control law can be designed as
u 0 = −p(ks + cė + f (x) −ÿ d + ηsgn(s)),
where η is a positive constant satisfying η ≥ D + bū a . Following the same analysis in the proof of Theorems 1-3, the cooperative design algorithm is still applicable in the presence of additive faults.


V. SIMULATION STUDY

In this section, a simulation study is presented to further demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm and evaluate its distinct properties. The simulation object is the upper arm of a deep-sea human-occupied vehicle, which is shown in Fig. 4.

In the deep-sea environment, the manipulator will be affected by the movement and uniform flow of sea water. Due to the unpredictable movement of water, only water's selfmotion is considered for modeling [42]. This robotic upper arm of the deep-sea human-occupied vehicle can be modeled as follows:
Mθ + 1 2 mgL sin(θ ) + P(θ) = τ + Md(40)
where θ represents the joint angle of the manipulator, M stands for the moment of inertia, m and L denote the mass and length of the link, respectively, g is the acceleration due to gravity, τ is the control torque, and d(t) is bounded external unknown disturbance satisfying |d(t)| ≤ 0.01. P includes the water resistance and the additional mass torque, which can be modelled as [42] 
P(θ) = 1 2 ρC d E L 0 lθ l θ l dl + 1 2 ρC M A L 0 lθldl (41)
where ρ is the density of the manipulator, C d is the resistance coefficient, E is the cross-sectional area of the manipulator, C M is inertia force coefficient, A is the projected area, and L Authorized licensed use limited to the terms of the applicable license agreement with IEEE. Restrictions apply.   (42) whereC d andC M are constants. Defining x 1 = θ , x 2 =θ , and u = τ , (40) can be rewritten aṡ
x 1 (t) = x 2 (t) x 2 (t) = f (x(t)) + 1 M u(t) + d(t) y(t) = x 1 (t) (43) where f (x(t)) = −C d +C M M x 2 (t) − mgL 2M sin(x 1 (t)).(44)
The initial conditions are set as x 1 (0) = 0 and x 2 (0) = 0. The objective is to ensure that the output y tracks the reference output signal y d = sin(0.5t). In this article, the parameters M = 2, m = 5, g = 9.8, L = 0.8C d = 1.6, andC M = 2.1 are used for simulation. The simulation time is 50 s.

The actuator fault occurs during 30-50 s with σ = 0.4, which means the input u 0 lost 60% of its effectiveness. The parameters of fault detection observer in (8) are given as l 1 = 20 and D 1 = 20, and the parameter of sliding-mode function is chosen as c = 0.2. The threshold is set as J th = 30. The operating parameters of DE algorithm are chosen as: the mutagenic factor is 1.2, the crossover factor is 0.6, the group size is 30, and the iterations is 20.

Case 1: When the CoD algorithm is not adopted, that is, the controller gains k and γ are arbitrarily selected. Table I shows the fault detection time with different controller gains, which are computed as averages over 100 independent Monte  Carlo experiments, and every experiment contains 50 s. We can observe from Table I that when different gains are selected, the fault detection time varies greatly.

In order to display more vividly, we show the simulation results in the case of k = 2 and γ = 1 in Figs. 5-7. It can be observed that the proposed fault-tolerant controller can tolerate the actuator fault by adjusting the input signal u 0 . However, the fault detection time is not the shortest.

Case 2: When the CoD algorithm is adopted, that is, one set of the suboptimal controller gains is solved by DE, which is [k * , γ * ] = [29.4666, 52.4959].

In the case of fault occurring, the results are shown in Figs. 8-11. Figs. 8 and 9 show the responses of system output y and state x 2 , which can be observed that the output tracking error converges to 0 and all states contained in the systems are uniformly bounded. The responses of designed input u 0   are shown in Fig. 10. It is shown in Fig. 11 that the fault is detected at t f = 30.326 s. Fig. 12 shows the response of J in the absence of fault, which illustrate there is no false alarm. From the simulation results, we can observe that the proposed CoD algorithm can ensure the good performance of FTC and the shortest fault detection time simultaneously.

Remark 9: In fact, the gains obtained by the designed CoD algorithm are actually suboptimal solutions, and there may be another set of gains guaranteeing the same shortest fault detection time.

Case 3: In order to show the effectiveness of the proposed CoD algorithm, a comparison is made with conventional proportion differential (PD) control technique. The control input   is u 0 (t) = K p (e r (t) + ([T D de r (t)]/dt)), where K p = 50 represents the proportion coefficient, and T D = 0.01 denotes the differential coefficient. Let e r (t) = y d (t)−y(t). The same initial conditions and the same parameters of fault detection observer are used. Fig. 13 shows the trajectories of y and y d . The tracking error e = y − y d is given in Fig. 14 and J is shown in Fig. 15. We can observe that the fault detection time is 32.291 s. It can be observed that the conventional PD algorithm cannot achieve satisfactory fault-tolerant performance, and the fault detection time is longer than that of the proposed algorithm.   


VI. CONCLUSION

The contradiction between the performance of FD and FTC is a common problem in many industrial applications. It has achieved a consensus that the FTC scheme would cover the fault symptom, which consequently raises the difficulty of FD. To bridge this gap, a novel framework for the cooperative design of FD and FTC has been proposed in this article. The innovation of this framework was to introduce AFD into the FTC. Within the proposed framework, the performance of the FD can be maximized while maintaining the admissible performance of FTC. The control law has been designed according to the system model, and suboptimal controller gains have been obtained by an intelligent optimization algorithm. We have shown that the proposed CoD framework can guarantee the performance of FTC, and can optimize the performance of FD to a certain extent by designing the input signal with a given fault detection observer. Simulation results have demonstrated the performance of the proposed CoD framework. It is interesting to apply the CoD framework to a high-order system or consider more complex constraints in the future.
